title: Histone H1 and heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1) regulate specific gene expression and not global transcription
Telomeric Position Effect Variegation in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by Caenorhabditis elegans Linker Histones Suggests a Mechanistic Connection between Germ Line and Telomeric Silencing
Analysis of Germline Chromatin Silencing by Double-Stranded RNA-Mediated Interference (RNAi) in <I>Caenorhabditis elegans<B>

items.abstract:
<jats:p>
            RNA interference with one of the eight
            <jats:italic>Caenorhabditis elegans</jats:italic>
            linker histone genes triggers desilencing of a repetitive transgene and developmental defects in the hermaphrodite germ line. These characteristics are similar to the phenotype of the
            <jats:italic>C. elegans</jats:italic>
            Polycomb group genes
            <jats:italic>mes-2</jats:italic>
            ,
            <jats:italic>mes-3</jats:italic>
            ,
            <jats:italic>mes-4</jats:italic>
            , and
            <jats:italic>mes-6</jats:italic>
            (M. A. Jedrusik and E. Schulze, Development
            <jats:bold>128:</jats:bold>
            1069-1080, 2001; I. Korf, Y. Fan, and S. Strome, Development
            <jats:bold>125:</jats:bold>
            2469-2478, 1998). These Polycomb group proteins contribute to germ line-specific chromatin modifications. Using a
            <jats:italic>his-24</jats:italic>
            deletion mutant and an isoform-specific antibody, we characterized the role of
            <jats:italic>his-24</jats:italic>
            in
            <jats:italic>C. elegans</jats:italic>
            germ line development. We describe an unexpected cytoplasmic retention of HIS-24 in peculiar granular structures. This phenomenon is confined to the developing germ lines of both sexes. It is strictly dependent on the activities of the chromatin-modifying genes
            <jats:italic>mes-2</jats:italic>
            ,
            <jats:italic>mes-3</jats:italic>
            ,
            <jats:italic>mes-4</jats:italic>
            , and
            <jats:italic>mes-6</jats:italic>
            , as well as on the
            <jats:italic>C. elegans</jats:italic>
            sirtuin gene
            <jats:italic>sir-2.1</jats:italic>
            . A temperature shift experiment with a
            <jats:italic>mes-3</jats:italic>
            (
            <jats:italic>ts</jats:italic>
            ) mutant revealed that
            <jats:italic>mes</jats:italic>
            gene activity is required in a time window ranging from L3 to the early L4 stage before the onset of meiosis. We find that the
            <jats:italic>his-24</jats:italic>
            (
            <jats:italic>ok1024</jats:italic>
            ) mutant germ line is characterized by an increased level of the activating H3K4 methylation mark concomitant with a decrease of the repressive H3K9 methylation. In the germ line of
            <jats:italic>his-24</jats:italic>
            (
            <jats:italic>ok1024</jats:italic>
            )
            <jats:italic>mes-3</jats:italic>
            (
            <jats:italic>bn35</jats:italic>
            ) double mutant animals, the repressive H3K27 methylation is more reduced than in the respective
            <jats:italic>mes</jats:italic>
            single mutant. These observations distinguish
            <jats:italic>his-24</jats:italic>
            as an unusual element in the developmental regulation of germ line chromatin structure in
            <jats:italic>C. elegans</jats:italic>
            .
          </jats:p>
title:
Linker Histone HIS-24 (H1.1) Cytoplasmic Retention Promotes Germ Line Development and Influences Histone H3 Methylation in
            Caenorhabditis elegans
On the ambident reactivity of .beta.-lactones in their reactions with alcoholates initiating polymerization
Oocyte Polarity and Its Developmental Significance
Dural Metastases of a Glioblastoma
